questions.question: Question 1: Sulfonamides are structural analogs of which of the following compounds?
questions.explanation:
Sulfonamides are structural analogs of para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) that interfere in the 
synthesis of folic acid. Sulfonamides competitively inhibit dihydropteroate synthase, the enzyme that is involved in the 
incorporation of PABA into pteridine (dihyropteroate diphosphate) to form dihydropteroic acid, 
which is an immediate precursor of folic acid. 439 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is not a topically used sulfonamide?
questions.explanation:
Sulfasalazine is a sulfonamide which is not used topically. It is used orally in the management of 
ulcerative colitis, rheumatoid arthritis, and regional enteritis. Sulfacetamide is used topically as eye drops for ophthalmic infections. Silver sulfadiazine and mafenide are used topically for the prevention of burn infections.

questions.question: Question 3: Trimethoprim is an inhibitor of which of the following enzymes?
questions.explanation:
Trimethoprim is a selective inhibitor of microbial dihydrofolate reductase. Dihydrofolate 
reductase is involved in the reduction of dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate. 440 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following combinations is indicated for the prophylaxis of malaria?
questions.explanation:
Sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine combination is used for prophylaxis and treatment of malaria caused 
by mefloquine-resistant strains of Plasmodium falciparum. Sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim is used in the treatment of Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia. Sulfadiazine-pyrimethamine is used in the treatment of toxoplasmosis.

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following options correctly describes the dose ratio of trimethoprim and 
sulfamethoxazole in co-trimoxazole?
questions.explanation:
Co-trimoxazole is a combination of trimethoprim with sulfamethoxazole in the dose ratio of 
1:5 (trimethoprim : sulfamethoxazole). The antimicrobial activity of this combination is because of its actions on sequential steps in the 
pathway of synthesis of tetrahydrofolic acid as shown in the image. Each agent alone usually exerts bacteriostatic activity. But when an organism is sensitive to both 
agents, bactericidal activity may be achieved. Because trimethoprim is more lipid-soluble than sulfamethoxazole, it has a larger volume of 
distribution than the latter drug. Therefore, when 1 part of trimethoprim is given with 5 parts of sulfamethoxazole (dose ratio is 1:5; 
trimethoprim:sulfamethoxazole), the peak plasma concentrations are in the ratio of 1:20, which is 
optimal for the combined effects of these drugs in vitro.

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following is the drug of choice for Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia prophylaxis 
in a patient who has undergone organ transplantation?
questions.explanation:
441 
Sold by @itachibot Cotrimoxazole is considered the drug of choice for Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia prophylaxis 
in immunocompromised patients like patients who have undergone organ transplantation and 
HIV-positive patients. Other drugs that can be used for prophylaxis are: • Aerosolized pentamidine • Dapsone • Dapsone plus pyrimethamine • Atovoquone

questions.question: Question 7: Co-trimoxazole is not prescribed in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Chancroid was earlier treated with cotrimoxazole but it is not used anymore because better 
alternatives like ceftriaxone, azithromycin, erythromycin, and ciprofloxacin exist. Options B & C: Cotrimoxazole is indicated in both upper and lower urinary tract infections 
and also in prostatitis. Option D: Patients with severe nocardiosis are initially treated with a combination including 
cotrimoxazole, amikacin, and ceftriaxone or imipenem.

questions.question:
Question 8: An infant had a serum bilirubin level of 33 mg/dL. The mother might have taken which of the 
following drugs during the third trimester for this to occur?
questions.explanation:
Cotrimoxazole is a combination drug consisting of trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole, of which 
sulfamethoxazole is a sulfonamide. Sulphonamides displace bilirubin from plasma albumin, 
leading to elevation of serum bilirubin levels. These drugs can cross the placenta and are secreted in milk and can therefore cause kernicterus 
in newborn infants if they are given to pregnant women near term or during lactation.

questions.question:
Question 9: A girl presents to the emergency room with severe abdominal pain, dark-colored urine, and 
seizures. You find out that she was recently prescribed co-trimoxazole for a UTI. What is the 
probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given neurovisceral symptoms following the use of sulfonamides point towards a diagnosis of 
acute intermittent porphyria (AIP). AIP is a rare heme biosynthesis disorder due to a partial deficiency of the enzyme 
porphobilinogen deaminase (PBGD). Diagnosis is made based on elevated urine PBG levels. 
Alcohol, infections, pregnancy, and certain medications can trigger attacks by inducing heme 
synthesis. This results in the accumulation of porphyrin precursors, causing symptoms. Side effects of sulfonamides are: • Acute intermittent porphyria - sulphonamides precipitate attacks • Hypersensitivity reaction - urticaria, erythema nodosum, erythema multiforme of the 
Stevens-Johnson type, exfoliative dermatitis, and photosensitivity 442 
Sold by @itachibot • Crystalluria - due to low solubility. It is treated with good hydration and alkalization of urine • Hemolysis in G-6-PD deficiency (sulphonamides are oxidizers) • Kernicterus in the newborn (displace bilirubin)

questions.question: Question 10: What is the mechanism of action of fluoroquinolones in gram-negative bacteria?
questions.explanation:
Fluoroquinolones inhibit two essential type II topoisomerases, DNA gyrase (in gram-negative 
bacteria) and topoisomerase IV (in gram-positive bacteria). DNA gyrase introduces negative supercoils and thereby reduces the torsional strain that occurs 
when double-stranded DNA is being unwound for replication or translation. Topoisomerases IV is 
responsible for unlinking daughter chromosomes after replication. Quinolone antibiotics form a 
complex with the topoisomerase enzyme and the DNA, and thereby block DNA replication and 
bacterial cell division.

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following fluoroquinolones has maximum bioavailability?
questions.explanation:
Levofloxacin and ofloxacin have the maximum bioavailability among fluoroquinolones. Hence, 
intravenous and oral doses are the same for these drugs.

questions.question:
Question 12: A patient who is a known case of cystic fibrosis presents to the OPD with complaints of fever 
and increased cough with expectoration. Sputum culture is positive for Pseudomonas 
aeruginosa. Which of the following fluoroquinolones can be used in this condition? 434 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Ciprofloxacin and levofloxacin have substantial activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and can 
be used in this patient. Mild to moderate respiratory exacerbations owing to Pseudomonas aeruginosa in patients with 
cystic fibrosis respond to oral ciprofloxacin or levofloxacin therapy. Activity against streptococci is significantly greater with newer quinolones like levofloxacin, 
gemifloxacin, and moxifloxacin. Moxifloxacin has clinically significant activity against anaerobes including B. fragilis. It is 
reported to have similar efficacy to piperacillin-tazobactam for complicated intra-abdominal 
infection.

questions.question:
Question 13: Which of the following quinolones is not approved for use in a patient diagnosed with urinary 
tract infection?
questions.explanation:
Moxifloxacin does not accumulate significantly in urine and is not approved for the treatment of 
urinary tract infections (UTIs). UTIs are the only indication for the use of nalidixic acid. Ciprofloxacin and norfloxacin can be 
used in UTIs caused by susceptible organisms. 443 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient presents with a wound on his leg with purulent discharge. Pus culture was positive 
for MRSA. Which of the following drugs will you prescribe?
questions.explanation:
Delafloxacin is a newer fluoroquinolone approved for use in acute bacterial skin and skin 
structural infections (ABSSSI) caused by susceptible bacteria including MRSA. Compared to other fluoroquinolones which are zwitterionic in nature, delafloxacin is anionic. This 
enables the molecule to achieve increased intracellular penetration and concentration, especially 
under acidic conditions (skin wounds). This results in increased antimicrobial activity and a 
decreased adverse event profile at clinically potent doses.

questions.question:
Question 15: Which of the following fluoroquinolones can be used in a patient with rifampicin-resistant 
leprosy?
questions.explanation:
Ofloxacin can be used in this patient as it is the fluoroquinolone that has high activity against M. 
leprae and is indicated in alternative multidrug therapy regimens for leprosy. It also has high 
activity against Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

questions.question:
Question 16: 435 
Sold by @itachibot A patient presents to the OPD with sudden onset abdominal cramps, fever, and diarrhea. He 
is a foreigner who is on a tour in India and is a known asthmatic on theophylline. You decide 
to start antibiotics. However, you would avoid ciprofloxacin in this patient because  
.

options.c: Ciprofloxacin decreases the effect of theophylline

questions.explanation:
Ciprofloxacin should not be given to this patient because it is a cytochrome P450 inhibitor 
and inhibits the metabolism of theophylline and can potentially lead to theophylline toxicity. Pefloxacin is another drug that inhibits the metabolism of theophylline and results in its toxicity.

questions.question:
Question 17: A 52-year-old man diagnosed with multi-drug resistant tuberculosis requires second-line 
agents for his therapy. However, he is found to have a creatinine clearance of 50 ml/min. 
Which of the following fluoroquinolones can be started in this patient without dosage 
adjustment?
questions.explanation:
Moxifloxacin is metabolized predominantly by the liver and hence can be used safely in patients 
with decreased renal function without dose adjustment. Fluoroquinolones, especially moxifloxacin, may be used as part of multiple-drug regimens for the 
treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis. Most of the available fluoroquinolones are cleared predominantly by kidneys and dosage needs to 
be adjusted in patients with renal failure. But fluoroquinolones such as moxifloxacin 
and pefloxacin undergo hepatic elimination and so should be used carefully in patients with liver 
disease.

questions.question:
Question 18: A 65-year-old man presents with symptoms suggestive of Achilles tendon rupture. He had 
undergone renal transplantation and is now being treated with an antimicrobial agent. Which 
of the following antimicrobials might he be on?
questions.explanation:
Among the following options, the most likely drug to have caused this condition is 
ciprofloxacin, since Achilles tendon rupture and tendinitis are side effects of quinolones. Elderly 
patients (>60 years), patients on corticosteroids and solid organ transplant recipients are at 444 
Sold by @itachibot higher risk.

questions.question:
Question 19: A 60-year-old woman undergoing treatment with moxifloxacin was brought to the casualty 
with delirium and seizures. According to her son, she had been taking diclofenac tablets over 
the counter to relieve her ankle pain, which recently started. Which of the following best 
describes the reason for her current ER admission? 436 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: Enhanced GABA binding to its receptor

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a fluoroquinolones drug interaction, where NSAIDs 
augmented the displacement of GABA from its receptors, leading to CNS excitation symptoms. Fluoroquinolones act as selective antagonists of GABAA receptors and thereby have the potential 
to cause CNS excitation. NSAIDs such as diclofenac cause the displacement of GABA from its 
receptors, further enhancing the neuropsychiatric adverse effects caused by fluoroquinolones.

questions.question:
Question 20: The ECG of a patient undergoing treatment with a quinolone is given below and you notice 
that QTc = 477 ms. Which of the following drugs has the highest risk of causing this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario describes QT interval prolongation (Normal QTc = 440 ms). Among the given 
options, moxifloxacin has the highest risk for causing this condition. Gemifloxacin, ofloxacin, and ciprofloxacin have a relatively lower risk than 
moxifloxacin. Ciprofloxacin has the least risk for QT interval prolongation and torsades de 
pointes. Sparfloxacin has the highest overall risk of QT prolongation and has been withdrawn 
from many countries due to its propensity to cause torsades de pointes or polymorphic ventricular 
tachycardia. Withdrawn Fluoroquinolones

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following is a urinary antiseptic?
questions.explanation:
Methenamine is a urinary antiseptic and is indicated in urinary tract infections. At pH<5.5, 
methenamine releases formaldehyde that inhibits bacteria. Option A: Galantamine is a central anticholinesterase approved for the treatment of Alzheimer's 
disease. Option C: Mecamylamine is a ganglionic blocker that can be used as an antihypertensive agent. Option D: Pyrimethamine is an antimalarial agent. 445 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 22: Which of the following drugs would you prescribe to a patient in order to relieve pain due to 
urinary tract infection?
questions.explanation:
Phenazopyridine can be prescribed to this patient since it is a urinary anesthetic. It is used as a 
local anesthetic in urinary tract disorders to relieve the pain of lower urinary tract irritation, as in 
cystitis, urethritis, or prostatitis. It does not have any antibacterial action but affords symptomatic relief of burning sensation, 
dysuria and urgency due to cystitis.

questions.question:
Question 23: A patient presents to the casualty with fever with chills and chest pain. He also gives history 
of passing brown-colored urine. He was prescribed an antimicrobial drug for urinary tract 
infection three days ago and his symptoms began after he had started this medication. Which 
of the following antimicrobial agents had most likely been prescribed?
questions.explanation:
The patient had most likely been prescribed nitrofurantoin as the scenario depicts side effects of 
this drug. Nitrofurantoin is a urinary antiseptic used against lower UTI caused by E.coli and enterococci. Its 
use results in brown urine. It is also associated with acute pneumonitis with fever, chills, cough, 
dyspnea, chest pain, pulmonary infiltration, and eosinophilia within hours to days of initiation of 
therapy. The symptoms resolve quickly after discontinuation of the drug. The antibacterial activity of nitrofurantoin is due to its intracellular conversion to highly reactive 
intermediates by bacterial reductases. These intermediates react nonspecifically with ribosomal 
proteins and disrupt the synthesis of proteins, RNA, DNA, and other metabolic processes.

questions.question: Question 24: Which of the following fluoroquinolone is not given in liver disease?
questions.explanation:
Pefloxacin is mainly metabolized in the liver and hence avoided in patients with liver disease. Quinolones with primarily hepatic metabolism include moxifloxacin, pefloxacin, and trovafloxacin 
(withdrawn from the market due to hepatotoxicity). Quinolones primarily excreted by the kidneys include ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, norfloxacin, 
lomefloxacin, and ofloxacin. 446 
Sold by @itachibot Antimicrobials Acting on 30s Subunit
